statement.p: Instructions call for producing a solution of sodium chloride that contains 9 g of the provided dry solute with 2000 mL of sterile water. What is the
dilution ratio: Preview Question 1 Part 1 of 3
dilution factor: Preview Question 1 Part 2 of 3
percent concentration: Preview Question 1 Part 3 of 3

solution.p: We use the definitions for solutions of dry ingredients in a solution.
The dilution ratio is defined to be grams of solute per mL of diluent added. We have 9 g of solute with 2000 mL of diluent added, so the ratio is 9/2000.

The dilution factor is defined to be grams of solute per mL of solution resulting. We have 9 g of solute in 2000 mL of diluent, so the ratio is 9/2000. Sometimes it is written as simply 2000. Note, this matches dilution ratio because the solute adds almost no volume to the solution (too small to measure).

The percent concentration is defined to be grams of solute per mL of solution resulting written as a percent. We have 9 g of solute in 2000 mL of diluent, so the percent is \displaystyle\frac{{9}}{{2000}}\cdot{100}={0.45}\%.
